commentBody:
My love of air travel started to take off. Then it ballooned.

(That's plane to see.)

Once AGAIN it's 4:37 PM Mountain Time & I cannot do the mini crossword because the SATURDAY mini is already superceded by TOMORROW'S mini ! üò† I pay to get the NY Times ! !    This  is  NOT  right !  
In the Era of getting everything in a minute, it SHOULD be possible to leave the mini available for the WHOLE CURRENT DAY ! üò§
Well this was a fun one! Lots of fresh fill and a bunch of entries I've not seen before. Congrats!
I had 20 Down as TYVM and 27 Across as BVMETER (body voltage meter) and couldn't find my error until I read the blog.

18 across the clue is MIA and the answer AWOL.
They are so not the same thing. And very offensive to any family whose loved one is in fact MIA -missing in action. As opposed to AWOL absent without leave.
I saw a killer robot from the Star Wars universe. My goddaughter saw a lion; her mother, a frog. Goes to show that puzzle art is in the eye of the beholder.

I can see clearly now, it‚Äôs a HOT AIR BALLOON!  What a fun aha moment.  I especially love UP, UP AND AWAY and BLOWIN‚Äô IN THE WIND. 

Regarding Caitlin‚Äôs comment that the four entries 23A, 101A, 4D and 14D ‚Äúenhance the theme‚Äù, from reading the constructor notes, I think it‚Äôs actually VICE VERSA and it's the ‚Äúwee‚Äù entries that enhance the theme. 

I like seeing WASHTUB after the recent ICEBOX entry. . 

Excellent clue for SLAPSHOT [Ice belt?]. 

Thanks, Rebecca and Ariela. It was a fun ride.
Is it Monday already?  (Ooh, I hope that doesn't trigger anyone.)

I really, really wanted 37A to be a "PuPoo".

(Tee hee)
It's called MAX now, just saying.
I'm a native portuguese speaker and AGUA somehow escaped me! It was one of my last entries. It's better than A√ßa√≠ anyways!

Well, someone has to throw this in, might as well be me: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BQiBq8YSTxc Nice Sunday; not as quick as I'd like, but got it done in a reasonable amount of time. Thanks, Rebecca and Ariela.
The Japanese ‚ÄúXIE XIE‚Äù is missing the U. It‚Äôs formally „ÅÇ„Çä„Åå„Å®„ÅÜ, not „ÅÇ„Çä„Åå„Å®

Charming!

I didn‚Äôt need the theme per se to pick up on the shrink-y trends. It felt very whimsical, in a good way!

But upon completing the puzzle I loved the strong mental image of just floating away, watching everything get smaller and smaller.

I knew I was going to like this puzzle when I discovered the hot air balloon in the grid. For many years I had my students build and launch hot air balloons as part of the unit on gases. I also loved the supporting clues that went along with the theme. I enjoyed most of the other clues as well such as the one which referenced Alsace, where my grandfather was born and the Mandarin:Japanese analogy. It was my idea of a fun Sunday crossword: doable, entertaining, and with a moderate level of challenge. The only clue I felt was a bit off was the one with M. I. A. I‚Äôm not sure that A. W. O. L. Is a particularly good answer because the terms can refer to very different situations.  Otherwise, I really enjoyed this.

Missed an excellent opportunity for 108-across to be LIDLVAN! 

Excellent puzzle as always, thanks.
Late to the party tonight because of real life, I was surprised no one commented that it‚Äôs proofreaders who catch typos, not EDS.

Nice enough hot air ride.  Though when I first noticed the puzzle title, the shape, and the very first clue (Webb), I thought for sure it would all be space based and that the image was supposed to be a big skyward pointing satellite dish.  Alas, not so.

There were parts I liked and parts I didn't, but I'm a little tired of crossword quibbling this week (not to mention other events this last week or so).  Enjoy the relatively easy Sunday folks, and catch you later.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

A fun puzzle with just enough crunch to make it interesting to me. I would have gotten nowhere without the "trivia." JayTee has already posted one of the songs this puzzle had me thinking of. Here's another from John Mellencamp. https://youtu.be/0CVLVaBECuc?si=HunQSEIpQQQsztnD
For 69 across‚Ä¶ we changed the name a couple years ago‚Ä¶ the clue should be Chicago‚Äôs DuSable Lake _____ Drive

I suggest a rule (or policy) by the Editors to avoid having a square that comes from two pieces of trivia, such as proper names, especially if the trivia is somewhat obscure. I didn't know either 70A (STEWIE) or 71D (ERIVO), and couldn't get their shared letter (E) without using the internet to get the answers, and I prefer to avoid that.

the west winds of the puzzle taught me new things. 

Overall, great fun.  My success went from 1 o clock, and then mostly clockwise from there.  Always fun to work in one spot and see it fall in order to get the confidence and mental juices flowing for the next one.

I see two songs linked in the comments, but not the one that first came to my mind when I saw the puzzle's title - I Can See Clearly Now by Jimmy Cliff https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D8QL9cSYGVM I also see some discussion of Naticks, but not the one I was expecting. I happen to know of Colin Jost and J-Lo, but I can very easily see people losing a gold star there by entering HOST for 90A

The clue that made me smile was 99A - fresh cut, crossing with 100 D -purveyors of pastrami.  Why am I craving an old-fashioned pastrami on rye? :)

Happy Sunday!

Enjoyed the puzzle after a slow start. 

I did have an issue with 105D being "A, not AN".
Lovely puzzle! I love when it feels like I‚Äôm on the same wavelength as the constructors. The solving was smooth as butter and the theme entries made me smile.

Alternate clue for 83 across: ‚ÄúFetch the devil!‚Äù
Hehe

AWOL is not even a close synonym for M.I.A.
The former refers to a violation of strict rules of presence and readiness, and can result in severe military discipline.
The latter refers to the potential loss of a service person, often as the result of enemy engagment.
It took me far too long to realize there's no G in BLOWIN' IN THE WIND.
Atlas isn‚Äôt outside of 30 Rock. That‚Äôs Prometheus.
The title of this crossword seems insensitive

I did not see a hot air balloon in this grid. I saw a person flipping me the double bird.

Maybe a subliminal representation of 3D?
Heaven! Thanks Ariel and Rebecca.

End of streak. Didn't finish this one; didn't even come close. Even after review I don't see how I could ever have gotten it. Lots of things that were never going to dawn on me from the clues. Actually surprised that everyone else found this one easy. Oh well. Puzzle find today: A Sunday from June 6, 2004 by Patrick Merrell with the title "Sunday Funnies." Not even going to try to describe it - will just say that all of the theme answers had 'cartoon' in the clue. Here's the Xword Info link if you care to go take a look: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/6/2004&g=2&d=D I return now to my home planet. ..

Possible alternate clue for 112A:
[What one looks like from a 93A]

Could someone tell me what "BOGO" is an acronym for?

Thank you.

wondering what BOGO means.
fun one today! took some time but not overly difficult. the theme was fun!

I‚Äôve never taken a hot air balloon ride, but I imagine it to be peaceful, lilting above the fray below, quiet, nothing to disturb you ‚Äì relaxing, like tubing down a lazy river.

Solving this puzzle had a similar calm feel to me ‚Äì a theme that required no mental gyrations, a theme that unfolded gently.  When I finished, I thought, ‚ÄúThat was sweet‚Äù and sat in reverie for a moment imagining a hot air balloon ride, a blissful escape that left me feeling wonderful.

Ahhh.  Puzzles can do that too.  Ain‚Äôt Crosslandia wonderful?

Not that my riddle-loving brain felt left out.  There was figuring out what the grid art was (looked like light bulb at first glance), and lovely wordplay to untangle in some clues, such as [Everyone in Georgia] for Y‚ÄôALL, [Ice belt] for SLAP SHOT, and [Kennedy for American, e.g.] for HUB.

There were also sparks along the way:
‚Ä¢	Things people wear not clued as things people wear (CAP, HOSE, SLING).
‚Ä¢	Lovely answers (PLAY GOD, I GET THAT A LOT).
‚Ä¢	Splendid PuzzPair¬© (ABUT and BUMS).
‚Ä¢	Abutting trio of long-O enders (BESO, BOGO, MOTTO).

All told, a fun and satisfying great escape, for which I‚Äôm eminently grateful.  Thank you, Rebecca and Ariela!
As long as folks are sharing their theme-related songs, here's my offering (in a cover I wouldn't expect, but I kinda like it): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pUm9SM6zqhU

Smooooth Sunday.

No playing Twister, no calisthenics,
just some fun,
uplifting clueing and solving.

Really liked the clues that got cut!

It‚Äôs better than a deuce in a flush?
C‚Äômon! That‚Äôs gold!

Happy Sunday all!
Charming & fun!

Macaroni art and grid pictures both make me tap dance.


(Liked the puzzle words. Off to vape some ink.)

I think BLOWIN IN THE WIND is the best song ever written, so nice to see in the puzzle today.  I also liked the interesting looking grid.  Fun idea for a theme.  As usual I needed help and as usual don‚Äôt mind getting it.

Looking forward to more from Rebecca and Ariela.
Did anyone else put this together? Jimmy WEBB (1A) wrote the song UP UP AND AWAY. I wonder if that was a coincidence. The constructor notes don't mention it.

I expect our constructors will be off to Albuquerque for the mass ascension.

Fun and smooth solve,

Thank you Rebecca and Ariela

Too, too many clues that basically hang on whether you watch as much (or the same) TV/ movies as the constructors. So many NYT crosswords like this these days. It just comes across as a very lazy way to increase difficulty, and is a far cry from the clever brain teasers and twists that these puzzles used to feature under a prior regime.

Smooth and charming.  Thanks. 

Clue for 83A, [Soaks up some sun] clearly cannot be solved to

GET SATAN

On a Sunday morning no less!  :)
Fun theme and well constructed.

I don't understand why they have to turn these grids into pop culture trivia fests. 
Also, the 20D/27A crossing is beyond unfair. V is a much more appropriate and fitting letter for both clues. The namesake of 27A is off the charts for this fiasco.
I saw the balloon right away and happened to solve down the left side first‚Äîso I thought the girl seen from a balloon had to be DOROTHY
The statue referenced in 34 down is located in front of 630 Fifth Avenue which, while part of Rock Center, is not 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

I hate that you can‚Äôt check puzzle without it messing up your statistics. Sometimes I get to the end of a long puzzle and it says that something‚Äôs wrong. 99% of the time I typoed something (usually my big fingers hitting the wrong letter while retyping an answer that‚Äôs been confirmed in pen instead of pencil) and it‚Äôs annoying to have to hunt that down. 

Alternately, I‚Äôd love if we could just pick an answer and mark it to be pen instead of pencil without having to retype it. That would solve most of my problems.

Interesting mix of comments.

I'm one who found it pretty easy, in shouting distance of my Sunday best. 

Still, I thought the constructors' approach of adding difficulty with a lot of very short words, must have been a challenge.  Somebody must know what the most three-letter answers in a Sunday is, but it occurred to me they might have been going for it.

Lots of unknown proper names for me, but nothing that couldn't be deduced or guessed from the crosses. 

As to 97D, I never knew it was a portmanteau, although it makes senses. Also never heard of Veet, but apparently NAIR isn't the only entry in that category.

Thanks!

So I wanted Dorothy or at least Toto to be in this puzzle - but the grid art was excellent - loved it . Agree totally about MIA and AWOL not being the same at all . As to the comment about Stewie and Cynthia Erivo - I think the latter is incredibly well known and currently everywhere in commercials , bus ads , magazines .. so an antic but really not impossible at all . Happy Thanksgiving to all - let the fun of puzzles take you up, up and away from the chaos of daily life !

I was disheartened to see that AWOL was equilibrated with MIA. Missing In Action is not the same as being Absent With Out Leave.  For the friends and families of those who have been or are now MIA in a military sense, it is a great disrespect to suggest that took off without permission.  Editors that clue could have been something else.

My favorite clue was 30A. At first I thought, how the heck am I ever going to get this? But with just a few crosses, the familiar Japanese word came to mind--and now I know a new Mandarin word as well.

Time for a second cup of coffee and learning how to pronounce the new word.
Re: 34 Down Two earlier posters have noted the error. Here is the evidence. https://www.untappedcities.com/atlas-prometheus-sculpture-rockefeller-center/ https://www.rockefellercenter.com/art/
loved loved loved seeing UNION in the connections puzzle today üíôüí™üí™üí™

Am I the only one who saw a stylized picture of a space alien‚Äôs head in the grid art? 1 across only reinforced this interpretation. As did the apparent smile in the middle of the face üëΩü§ì


   
.:.:.:.:.


 .:.:.:.


  .:.:.

Approximately 143 clues (I kept getting interrupted while counting) and approximately 26 proper nouns, including NESS, AUDIS, IAGO and maybe ERIE (Have I mentioned my short term memory problems?)
My calculator says that works out to approximately 18% of the clues are proper nouns.  That seems pretty low to me.

FYI: RE: 34 D clue. The statue of Atlas is locared in front of 650 5th Ave, known as The International Building. The closest statue to the front door of 30 Rockefeller Plaza is the gilded statue of Prometheus.

A very fun puzzle!  I had only one 'typo', erm, "ERROR".  I had "host" for "JOST", (I've not heard of this term, but 'JLO' does make more sense in the crossing than 'hlo'.  I hope to see more of Goldstein and/or Perlman's efforts in the future.  Thank you!
What is a HIVE mind?

Sticks and stones can break more than bones and even letters can hurt you. I‚Äôm sorry to see this wonderfully lighthearted puzzle, otherwise so enjoyable, marred by the insensitive MIA/AWOL clueing. The editors really let the constructors down on this one. Hippocrates may or may not have said it, but ‚ÄòDo no harm‚Äô is a good motto. In its long and distinguished history, the NYT Crossword has included other examples of unseemly clueing. Good riddance to all of them and precedent is no excuse. There is no way to tap dance around this.
Sorry for the rant, but even a neutral Helvetian was dismayed by the lack of respect.

I think the MIA/AWOL issue in the puzzle today merits a letter to Joel Fagliano. While I'm  100% certain that it was done out of ignorance and not malice, I was disheartened to learn that there was much discussion about the same issue in the past, and yet here we are again.  My best idea is to contact him, but if someone has a better idea, please let me know.  I doubt the editorial staff reads the comments on a regular basis, so it seems that a more direct approach could be helpful.

Sun is shining in the sky,
There ain't a cloud in sight,
It's stopped raining, everybody's in the play,
And don't you know,
It's a beautiful new day! Hey hey.

On a not-so-related note, did anyone else think of (Little) PINK HOUSEs for 65A, after getting 39A? Because John Cougar.

I loved this puzzle.  The clever clueing was right for my brain wave pattern and the misdirects were readily solved with crosses.  I knew most of the proper names less one letter.  Perfectly easy to start, perfectly challenging to finish.  
Btw to a complainer, one can "pencil" answers in with the little button at top  right , in the left side of the row of choices.
107A's clue "upper underwear" made me laugh. It sounds like a 7th grade boy's way of trying desperately to avoid saying the word "BRA".
I figured out it was a HOT AIR BALLOON pretty quick, but didn't fully grasp the theme, so I had Dorothy in at 104A for a long time, which complicated things.
To jump on the bandwagon, the theme ‚Äútriggered‚Äù (apologies to Willie‚Äôs Martin acoustic) this song for me. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=SY2CLJPlLV8
Welp, guess I gotta bone up on my Chinese and Japanese now ü§î
Atlas, Prometheus--you've seen one Titan, you've seen them all.

Way too many names! I suppose I should have come up with WEBB without looking up "jasmyn," but I have trouble even with the things I supposedly know nowadays.
I ran the alphabet once mentally, then with the keyboard, for the J in JOST, my final fill. Yes, THEN I recognized JLO but I didn't know she had ever been on SNL

While so many people are outraged by editing or lack thereof, I will  add a current complaint and hope that Joe Fogliano and any other editors read it and take it to heart . I also hope that others agree with me.  In recent weeks I have noticed an acceleration and multiplication of repeated clues within a week or two.  these are readily discernible. It seems like AI is being used to construct the puzzles and is collecting or ignoring repetition. I hope I I am wrong.  This would be a more serious outrage than any other, in my book.

Not one, not two, but THREE Naticks in one puzzle. So much for the Times ‚Äústrict rules‚Äù about creating. Too many names of vague ‚Äúcelebrities‚Äù is a cheap way to fill a puzzle, and I‚Äôm tired of it, because it makes for a frustrating solve. 

 Also‚Ä¶ AWOL and MIA are two completely different designations for a missing person, and to clue them as synonyms is offensive to any family with a loved one who is Missing in Action. 

It‚Äôs too bad, because the theme (and all the related phrases) was a good one a could have been a very satisfying and fun solve, if one didn‚Äôt have to keep going through the entire alphabet on more than one or two squares.
It was OK. Grid shape based themes are not my favorite. They create insular pockets, and generally make the puzzle not as much fun. This was a fairly easy solve though.
For now on, whenever I see someone crispy on the beach I‚Äôm going to assume they‚Äôre there to GET SATAN.

I've only been doing this crossword for a few weeks and a hair removal cream has been a solution 3 times, which seems funny to me!
Too many names and trivia for me, but I got a lot from the crossers.
I find two-constructor puzzles tend to have too many specialized answers.

Usually AWOL is an irresponsible person who got drunk and forgot to report. MIA is someone who didn't return from a patrol or mission. I knew a family who's dad was MIA from 1962 until a few years ago when his dog tags and some other articles were discovered in a Vietnam hillside where his plane crashed. He didn't get drunk and forget to report for duty.
It‚Äôs already noted but I want to reiterate: AWOL and MIA are not synonyms.

I'm tired of the Super Mario clues that seem to appear way too frequently. Just boring.
AWOL/MIA clueing was wrong. Why do they keep making this same mistake?
FYI re 34D, for those of us who aren't familiar with NYC, it might as well have been clued as [Statue]...
My flyspeck square was the S in BSMETER. My normal texted reply of gratitude is TYVM.
AWOL not the same as MIA,  HBO has been called MAX for quite a while now. I expect you already know these things though.
Can someone help me understand ‚ÄúHOMES component‚Äù when I google homes in all caps it doesn‚Äôt help me understand why Erie is the answer.

While I understand people pointing out the difference between MIA and AWOL, I do think there‚Äôs a bit more to the story. MIA as a military term has a specific meaning, but colloquially it has become a somewhat tongue in cheek way to say a person is absent or inaccessible. AWOL has a separate military meaning, but the colloquial usage has evolved in the same way. Personally, I‚Äôve heard both MIA and AWOL used in meetings where one participant was meant to join but didn‚Äôt and is now not answering their phone. It‚Äôs a bit of a stretch, and I feel like the clueing should hint at informal usage if they‚Äôre going that route to connect the two. But I do think it‚Äôs defensible.

Yet another disappointment. The last two weeks have mostly been so, a change from norm. The comment that AI maybe being used is worthy Q. Please don't.
Too many trivia clues & very obscure.
Obscure clues which don't elicit aha once you see them.
NYT fix it.

Doug and I had a blast doing this puzzle. We absolutely loved it although there were moments we, um, struggled.  Thank you, once again, great Sunday morning entertainment. Rebecca & Ariela, you make a great team!
Here's a NYT Sunday puzzle from the good old days when there was no trivia. Give it a try. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Solve?psdate=2/15/1942

I really liked this puzzle. I thought the clueing was fun and made me think, but not so hard that I had to step away multiple times. I loved the theme and thought they did a great job. I‚Äôve read through some of the comments and I see many are peeved about the M.I.A. clue. I was in the USAF and I knew they were going for AWOL immediately.  I wasn‚Äôt offended or anything because I always assume (maybe wrongly) that most of the puzzles are created by lifelong civilians and they don‚Äôt really know much about the military.  It didn‚Äôt take away from the fun of the puzzle for me.

It‚Äôs rare anymore that a Sunday puzzle can hold my interest. This one did. I enjoyed it and appreciate it. I found it clever and sweet. A balm in a difficult world. 

I didn‚Äôt expect the negativity and extreme nitpicking in the comments. Is everyone considering this forum an easy place to vent after a tough couple of weeks? If so, while understandable, it‚Äôs sad. We need to nurture our balms.
I breezed through this one. Fun clues and an interesting grid. Somehow I knew all the trivia in this one. My BS meter didn‚Äôt go off the charts as so frequently it does.

I did both today's Sunday puzzle and yesterday Saturday puzzle on the drive home from an out-of-town funeral today. What a tale of two different puzzles!!  Enjoyed both but solved today's in a small fraction of the time it took me to do Saturday's. 

I was surprised by the column's inclusion of MACARONI ART as tricky or that it was hard to find a picture of it. I plugged that answer in immediately, on my first go through. And it may have been my favorite in the puzzle for nostalgia reasons.

A quick Google brought up a whole lot of macaroni art pictures and ideas that are a whole lot fancier than any I did back in the day.  

Anyhow, I am very tired from our weekend but I will second and third all of the comments about AWOL and mia. I have no personal experience with anyone MIA nor have I military experience but that just rubbed me at the wrong way and I resisted putting it in until I had no choice. I understand that things take on new, sometimes watered down, meanings, but I think some things should be held sacred and I would argue that this is one of them.

Otherwise a fun and charming puzzle after a fun but relatively brutal Saturday.  There were way too many comments yesterday for me to weed through a day later, so I don't know what the consensus was but I really loved FAMOUS POTATOES.

I enjoyed seeing COGNATE as it's something I talk about often in my ESL classes. My Spanish-speaking English learners benefit greatly from the Roman and Norman invasions of England. 

I agree a few of the names were pretty obscure, but it didn't ruin the puzzle for me. I looked up Erivo for my last letter just to avoid going through the alphabet. Fun theme. WEELASS was my favorite themed answer.
Once again reading oldest first is so rewarding. Good puzzle fun.
Too many names that I don‚Äôt know and can live my life without knowing, thanks very much. What‚Äôs going on lately with all the proper nouns?  That‚Äôs just no fun to solve. Wish it would stop.
American (the airline) has hubs at Chicago, Dallas, Phoenix, and Charlotte, but, regrettably, not at Kennedy. So 111 down threw me.
As I sit here in O‚ÄôHare‚Äôs Terminal 3 and stare wistfully out the window at so many flights that are, unlike mine, leaving O‚ÄôHare, I really, realllly want 23A to be UP UP AN‚Äô DELAY.

As I contemplated today‚Äôs brilliant grid art and how integral it was to the theme, a kind of obvious question struck me: why are all grids symmetrical? I know they have different kinds of symmetry, but is there a reason (other than aesthetics) that constructors so consistently eschew asymmetry?
So THIS is what an evening in Natick is like.
I see a cartoony fox or cat sitting. I see the eyes, ears, the hands and feet.  Not so much the hot air balloon.

Mike,

The pun also rises.

@Mike 
Is aviation an avocation or a vacation.

(Sorry to taxi you with such a question, but I wanted to know if it was a flight of fancy.)

What's the emus' favorite airline?
@Mike you know how loved you are, but what a treat to see you as first comment!
@Kate R Not trying to be rude, but the archive exists.
@Kate R the puzzles move to the next day at 6 PM Eastern on the weekends and 10 PM on the weekdays. It's been like that for years

@Kate R 
*Once AGAIN‚Ä¶*
It‚Äôs got to be pretty frustrating that it just keeps happening.
( Õ°¬∞ Õú ñ Õ°¬∞)
(From the columns link )

@Joshua Cooper 
I did exactly the same and gave up. Must be a Colorado thing.

@coloradoz 

Me, too.
@Joshua Cooper Figured it out without the blog, but that was also my only wrong letter ... (also in Ft Collins)

Shelly,

American English slang uses both MIA and AWOL to mean being mentally not (all) there. As a veteran, and as one with family and friends in various armed forces past and present, I cringed when I saw the clue and answer, but it is in the language.

@Shelly ,
I agree! I'm not a veteran or a family member of a MIA, but this still strikes me wrong.  Even if Barry Ancona is right that it's American slang--and I've never heard it despite living in the US--it's still offensive.  And wholly unnecessary, since there are dozens of better ways to clue AWOL.
@Barry Ancona Yes, but they are military terms of art that should be respected. A better clue was called for here.
Shelly, FWIW, here is a link to the thread from September 7, 2018, when MIA was clued as [AWOL, so to speak]. https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/r6coe?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

So much fir NYT links. See if this one will get you to Wordplay, start with the Oldest comments, and look for the thread started by Fact Boy. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/06/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2018-09-07.html?unlocked_article_code=1.ak4.UYpM.TTOrErRvurEi&smid=url-share

@Shelly 

I kept trying to make it something else because I could not believe that the fill would be what it in fact was.  How could the editors let that pass?  Didn't they know that it would seem utterly insensitive to call a person who could be dead or in a prisoner camp somewhere "absent without official leave"?  Time for an apology.

@Adina 

Completely agree. And it's so often the case that there are better ways to clue things. While I loved today's puzzle otherwise, there were far too many entertainment/pop culture clues for my liking, quite a few of which could have been clued in a more neutral way.

@Shelly 

I almost never agree with complaints about cluing, but I agree with you 100% on this one.  Both terms may be used by the civilian population to mean roughly the same thing, but there's just too much pain behind MIA to use it so frivolously.  I think this was a rare miss on the part of the editorial team.

@Shelly I am of the Vietnam war generation and I winced as well, then flipped my thinking toward today's slang and understood the clue. But it got me thinking.

Most people here today probably have no memories of friends on campus wearing their MIA bracelets with wrists turned green from the copper because the person whose name they wore has not come back. Your comment--and others like it below--brought back that unbearable sense of waiting for someone you will only ever know as a name, because they, unlike you, are not present in freshman class.

@Lynn 
Should have said "others like it above."

@Barry Ancona You did a fine job explaining this.

For the rest of you, let those who take offense at words also take the actions to resolve them.

If you're this upset about MIA vs AWOL (as we all should be), find an unresolved MIA case, make it your own, and contact a member of Congress for help - never letting up until the family has relief. 

Don't think that a snit in the Crossword comments about offensiveness gets you off the hook for culpability - having announced your emotional commitment to the topic in writing, if you walk away now, you are clearly part of the problem. 

Do something.

"The ultimate tragedy is not the oppression and cruelty by the bad people but the silence over that by the good people." - Martin Luther King, Jr.

@Malcolm 

The good news is that we can do both.  We can act, and we can comment.  The two are not mutually exclusive.

Anita,

I think Caitlin has it right.

The four "wee" entries -- 39A, 65A, 104A, 108A -- are the official themers (as their clues should make clear).

One revealer and four themers make a rather thin Sunday theme, so I was glad there were a fair number of unofficial themers.
Point taken, thanks Barry.

Anita,

I too liked the SLAPSHOT clue!

@Anita

The "arigatou" spelling in Roman letters is relatively new, inspired I believe by computer usage. Back in the old (my young) days it was spelt as pronounced by English speakers and written "arigat≈ç" for those who needed the Japanese pronunciation, an "o" held for two beats. @Alex Barry I came here to say the same thing. This clue and answer pairing is somewhere north of insensitive and closer to an outrage. 
We‚Äôre two generations past a time when most Americans might easily know someone who risks dying as an ‚Äúunknown soldier‚Äù or whose remains are never recovered. That‚Äôs a good thing, and maybe the constructors are younger and can‚Äôt be held responsible for knowing the difference, but at least one of the editors should.

As I noted in the earlier thread on this subject, MIA and AWOL are equivalent slang terms for "just not being there" (physically or mentally). Since a clue and answer need only be correct in some way or usage, the combo is "valid." It is also in very poor taste, and mars an otherwise delightful puzzle.

@Barry Ancona

I find your insinuation that this puzzle was full of obscure trivia surprising. I went to play your linked puzzle and was immediately hit with 3 clues in the top left corner that felt like obscure trivia to *me*. I don‚Äôt know generals, French physicists, or what BPOE stands for. If I committed to the whole puzzle, I‚Äôd hope I could start filling in crosses and figure them out.

In nearly every puzzle the Times publishes, I see a comment along these lines. Might some trivia deemed ‚Äúobscure‚Äù for you be common knowledge for another?

I expect crossword puzzle clues to change as time passes. When I started to do the puzzle in your link, I struggled with the clues more than I do with current puzzles. Likely because I am a different age or of different cultural experience than you. Or a byproduct of two puzzles created at different times.

I checked this Sunday‚Äôs puzzle again after seeing a few comments along your lines. There were a few names or trivia that I also did not know, but I figured them out via crossing words and some educated guesses for spellings. For example, when I had STE_IE, I thought a W made the most sense. Obscur for me, but now I know something new about a sport rising in popularity (women‚Äôs basketball).

In the grand scheme of things, I am relatively new to crosswords. Maybe there‚Äôll come a day when I find the clueing annoying or too niche. But I hope I remain open to what I learn from the process.
